Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Increasing the power of single-molecule bio-imaging with plasmon-enhanced fluorescence
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Julie Biteen and her group at the University of Michigan are improving the power of microscopes in order to look inside live cells at the 1-2 nanometer scale of proteins themselves. This project is based on coupling single-molecule fluorescence microscopy and metal nanoparticle plasmonics to produce a non-perturbative method for looking at protein position and dynamics in the natural cellular environment with unprecedented resolution and flexibility.

The interdisciplinary approach aims (1) to understand the mechanism of plasmon-enhanced single-molecule fluorescence, (2) to characterize plasmonic surfaces based on this insight, (3) to localize and track membrane proteins in live bacteria cells coupled to metal nanoparticles, and (4) to expose students to modern science through demos, mentoring, teaching and laboratory research, with a particular eye toward increasing the participation of women in STEM fields. The proposed research promises to enable non-invasive, nanometer-scale microscopy with applications ranging from live-cell imaging to in situ device characterization. The mechanistic understanding of nanoscopic details derived from plasmon-enhanced single-molecule fluorescence will have enormous implications for cell biology, hydrogen storage, chemical separation and energy production.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fluorescence imaging provides a non-invasive measurement tool to examine features in living cells, and single-molecule fluorescence microscopy sensitively detects one molecule at a time to provide very high-resolution images. Unfortunately, though single-molecule microscopy approaches can theoretically provide unlimited "super-resolution" capabilities, the resolution of single-molecule fluorescence imaging in cells is generally limited by the finite brightness of fluorescent proteins, which are the most experimentally ideal labels. Practically, the resolution of single-molecule microscopy is therefore insufficient to resolve individual subcellular events such as protein-protein binding. A general, biocompatible approach that enhances brightness and therefore resolution while permitting standard fluorescent labeling schemes was therefore desired.

To address this need, our NSF-funded project improved the resolution and speed of super-resolution imaging by enhancing fluorescence with nearby plasmonic nanoparticles. Nanoparticles made from noble metals such as gold act as optical light antennas: they can focus and redirect visible light. Through such light-matter interactions, these nanoparticles can enhance the brightness of nearby fluorescent dyes. Gold nanoparticles are also nontoxic and therefore compatible with live-cell imaging experiments. With NSF support, our team has demonstrated plasmon-coupled fluorescence from single fluorescent protein labels, both in a test tube and inside living cells. We found that coupling fluorescent proteins to gold nanoparticles leads to increased brightness and we identified the conditions for optimal enhancement. Furthermore, we used single-molecule microscopy experiments and optics simulations to understand how fluorescence emission is redirected upon coupling to a nanoparticle.

This multidisciplinary project bridged components from Physics, Chemistry, and Microbiology. In addition to training graduate and undergraduate students in nano-optics in the context of this project, we have reached out to K-12 students and the general public both in person (through hands-on demos and public seminars) and virtually (through online conversations) to explain the impact of optics and nanoscience and to promote an image of science as an exciting, attainable profession.
